"step_by_step_thinking": "The question is about the most likely lymphatic route for ovarian cancer to metastasize to the brain. The patient has stage 4 ovarian cancer with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain. Central nervous system involvement by ovarian carcinoma: a complication of prolonged survival with metastatic disease mentions that five of the six patients had previously received chemotherapy and had developed metastatic spread to extraperitoneal sites. This suggests that the patient in this case also has undergone chemotherapy, which may have led to the development of occult CNS metastases.

Intracranial metastases to the pineal region report a rare site for metastatic involvement of systemic malignant tumors. Spinal dissemination following operation on cerebral oligodendroglioma mentions leptomeningeal spread, which is also relevant to this case.

Spectrum of symptomatic brain-stem metastasis does not provide any information specific to lymphatic routes or ovarian cancer metastases.

Considering the rarity of central nervous system involvement by ovarian carcinoma and the development of occult CNS metastases, it is likely that the malignancy has spread through a similar route. The most relevant literature is Central nervous system involvement by ovarian carcinoma: a complication of prolonged survival with metastatic disease, which discusses the spread to extraperitoneal sites.

The relevant lymphatic route is the thoracic duct, which drains into the left subclavian vein and then into the systemic circulation.",
